bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 3, 1944

div1.p: Truby appreciates receiving the copy of a letter written by Walter Reed. He identifies persons in an old photograph. Truby asks for a copy of a different Walter Reed letter and comments on Kean's interview. He encloses a letter from Lawrence Reed complimenting Truby's book.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, October 3, 1944
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
October 3, 1944.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I was pleased to get your letter of September 1 enclosing the
copy of Walter Reed's New Years Eve letter to his wife in 1900. I
was also very much pleased to see the photograph of the group around
the ambulance at Camp Lazear. That was very familiar to me. I am
returning the photograph with remarks on the back of it. No. 2 is
certainly Dr. Cooke. I am quite sure that No. 3 is Jernegan. No. 4
is, I am quite sure, acting Servant Kissinger. The picture certainly looks exactly
like Kissinger's outline and is not at all like the two other acting
stewards we had in Cuba. No. 6 is evidently a young officer in a blue
flannel shirt and officer's blue uniform cap. I have no idea who it
is. After studying this photograph a long time, I am almost certain
that No. 7 is Walter Reed himself, although I never saw Walter Reed
wear civilian clothes in Cuba. This was evidently one of those cold
days there when woolen uniforms felt comfortable. If that is
Kissinger in the picture it means that this photograph was taken
late in December or in January, for Kissinger was promoted after his
attack of Yellow Fever. Reed probably had no blue uniforms with him,
but had civilian clothes to wear after he left the boat in New York
on his way to Washington. The three men with (No. 10) look exactly
like the Spanish volunteers. The boys were evidently their friends
who could visit them at that place. I hope you will get Dr. Cooke
to express his views and you should also write toask the Reed family if
7 is really Reed.

Do you still have Walter Reed's letters, and were there any more
comments in them about me? I would certainly like to have a photo-
stat copy of those nice remarks he made about me in his letter of
November 20, '99.

I know your professional work is keeping you busy and you do not
have much time for this hobby of yours. I think your interview with
Kean on January 6, '44 is really important and my comments on Kean's
replies to your questionnaire are important too. I would like to
know what Kean thinks about the Sibley stove suggestion of mine and
I would also like to know his comments on the funerals .
Won't you send it to him and have him comment on the margin. Are you
making any progress with young Carroll about getting those notebooks.
I think he would sell them.

I am feeling very well, but as you know progress after a certain
stage is terribly slow. I am enclosing a letter from Lawrence Reed
about my book which I thought you would be interested in seeing. I
have the original so you need not return this copy.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Albert E. Truby (Over)

T

would not go in the envelope and so cut off
the top & bottom, forgetting that I had written on
the back, So I patched it up-
I have just had a nice letter from Dr Hewitt
enclosing a newspaper clipping about Moran's
visit to Rochester. It was very nice and us

A E T
